ColPhysicalDescription: Wooden cabinet of 'Materia Medica' - herbs, minerals and other substances used in traditional medicine. This box was intended as a teaching aid for medical students

LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), North Tyneside, Whitley Bay

NarNarrative: This species is a hardy grass that can be found throughout North America, Europe and Asia. It has also been introduced to Australia and New Zealand. It is common in upland areas on poor soils, but tolerates a broad range of environmental conditions. Its name, Viviparous Fescue, refers to the fact that the adult plant produces seedlings rather than seeds.

A hardy grass species that is found throughout the northern hemisphere. It grows up to 25cm high. It grows on a variety of different soil types, and can withstand drought conditions and winter temperatures down to about 35 degrees below zero. It can also withstand heavy grazing and is a nutritious fodder species for livestock, although it generally produces low yields.

This is a very common and widespread species which occurs throughout Europe, Asia and North America. It grows on moist, nutrient rich soils. It is very nutritious and withstands heavy grazing, as well as being very palatable to livestock. This makes it an important agricultural species.

Perennial Rye-Grass is a temperate zone grass species that prefers moist, nutrient rich soils. It is a very important fodder crop for livestock due to its high nitrogen content, rapid growth rate and ability to withstand heavy grazing. For this reason it has been grown all over the world. It is also used to make hay and silage. Many different varieties have been bred.

This species grows on moist, nutrient rich soils in temperate areas with moderate climates throughout Europe and North America. It can be found in damp grassland areas, woodland and marshes. It flowers during June and July. It is a widespread and abundant species.

This species is a small grass that is found mainly in coastal areas. It is native to Europe, north Africa and temperate Asia, and has been introduced to Western Australia, where it is a significant weed species. It is extremely drought and heat tolerant and normally grows in dry, sandy soils.

NarNarrative: This is a small fern which grows throughout Eurasia and North America. It produces dense upright tufts of leaves and prefers rocky environments such as mountain slopes and cliffs. It is normally found on slate or calcareous rocks, particularly limestone. The name 'Woodsia' comes from the botanist Joseph Woods (1776-1864) who first described the species.

This is a small plant that grows in damp, shaded environments. It is commonly found growing in rock crevices and on the forest floor in deep shade. It has a superficial resemblance to tufts of moss. The tiny leaves are very thin and are semi-transparent, hence the name 'filmy-fern'. It is found growing in suitable conditions all over the British Isles.

SciName: Rubus plicatus var. bertramii : Rosaceae : Rosales : :

ColPhysicalDescription: A large seedpod consisting of seven seeds in a hard wood-like pod. At one end is the short stem that attached the pod to the parent plant. This appears to have been cut in half lengthways. A historic paper label is attached to the fourth seed from the top of the pod, and the entire specimen is sealed into a polythene bag.
ComName_tab: Sea Bean, Mackie Bean, Cacoon Vine

NarNarrative: The Common Dog Violet is widespread throughout Britain and Europe. It grows in deciduous woodland as well as a variety of grassland environments, on both acid and calcareous soils. The flowers vary in colour from dark bluish-purple to white. The violet has a specialised seedpod that bursts open when ripe, spraying seeds out up to a metre from the parent plant. In this way the violet can disperse it's seeds over relatively long distances.
SciName: Viola riviniana reichenb. : Violaceae : Malpighiales : : Spermatophyta

NarNarrative: The Maiden Pink lives in a variety of different habitats throughout Europe and temperate Asia. It is a perennial herb with bright pink flowers that forms dense mats in dry, sunny places. It normally prefers light, well drained, alkaline soils and is often found along roads and on patches of waste ground.

ColPhysicalDescription: Plant 'Plantae & Magnoliaphyta & Magnoliopsida & Myrtales & Thymelaeaceae & Daphne : : : :'
NarNarrative: Daphne sericea forms low growing, dense bushes that produce fragrant pink flowers. This species is native to the southern Mediterranean region but has become naturalised in many areas, including parts of North America. It is often grown as an ornamental plant due to its flowers and strong fragrance.
SciName: Plantae & Magnoliaphyta & Magnoliopsida & Myrtales & Thymelaeaceae & Daphne : : : :

NarNarrative: This low growing plant is found in coastal areas across Europe and Asia. It has also become naturalised in North America. It is adapted to sandy, salty environments and is particularly common on saltmarshes. It has thick and fleshy leaves that store water, and produces lots of small pink flowers during the summer.
LocalSum: Europe, France, Var, Sea Shore Near Almanarre

NarNarrative: This low growing plant is found in coastal areas across Europe and Asia. It has also become naturalised in North America. It is adapted to sandy, salty environments and is particularly common on saltmarshes. It has thick and fleshy leaves that store water, and produces lots of small pink flowers during the summer.
LocalSum: Europe, France, Var, Hyeres, Mt Des Oiseaux, Woods

NarNarrative: This short and rather delicate plant produces white flowers and small leaves that have a swelling or 'knot' at the base, hence its common name. It grows on damp sandy or peaty soils, including sand dunes in coastal areas.

NarNarrative: This is a tall, upright flowering plant is a member of the Borage family that grows on well drained sandy or calcareous soils in sunny areas. It produces dense stalks of bright blue flowers. It is naturally occurring on dry grassland, often near the coast. However, it is an opportunistic species and is also found on bare slopes or recently disturbed ground such as building sites.

This small plant is found in damp, marshy places. It often grows on very nutrient poor soils, such as bogs in upland areas. It supplements its supply of nutrients by catching insects. The rosette of small yellowish leaves at the base of the plant are covered with sticky glands that trap and digest small beetles and flies. It produces a single purple flower that grows on a long stem at the centre of the rosette of leaves.

This species occurs throughout Europe and Asia. It forms dense prickly clumps of sharply pointed leaves that grow up to about a metre high. It produces small tufts of brown flowers that grow sideways out from the stem. The seeds germinate in damp conditions on a wide variety of soils, frequently alongside ponds and rivers. However, the plant does not require wet soil once it is established.
LocalSum: UK, England, Devon, Bideford, Braunton Burrows

NarNarrative: This is a very hardy species that is found in alpine meadows throughout the northern temperate and arctic regions. It grows on wet sites in shallow soils as well as sand and gravel, and will tolerate temporary flooding. It occurs up to the snowline in the Rocky Mountains of North America, and can withstand ice and severe frosts. It is not normally a dominant species, and is most often found growing in association with other rushes, sedges and herbaceous species.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Tayside (Scotland), Forfar, Clova, Glen Dole

NarNarrative: This species is a generalist, and is common throughout the northern hemisphere. It grows in a wide variety of conditions, including coastal marshes and estuaries, beaches, moorland, around freshwater lakes and ponds and arctic tundra. It has been recorded from sea level up to about 2000 ft. It often forms dense mats in wet or flooded areas.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Tayside (Scotland), Sands of Barrie

NarNarrative: A common and widespread sedge that is found in wet environments such as upland moorland, marshes and coastal areas. It is easily recognised by its fruit, which are shiny and dark brown, and are said to resemble several fleas attached to the stem.
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria, The Gelt (near), Gelt House Farm

NarNarrative: This tall reedy plant is found in marshy places all over the world. It is a rapid coloniser of exposed wet soil and shallow water, and will tolerate a broad range of environmental conditions. Common habitats include wet meadows, marshes, fens, pond and lake margins and coastal estuaries. It is an important source of food and habitat for many animals. It has also been used by humans to produce a wide range of materials including baskets, roofing material and paper.
SciName: Plantae & Magnoliaphyta & Lilopsida & Typhales & Typhaceae & Typha : : : :

NarNarrative: This species is native to Europe and Asia. It grows on damp, acid soils, and can normally be found in swampy woodland and moorland areas. The leaves are very stiff and sharply pointed at the tip, and grow upright to a height of about a metre. It produces small clusters of brown flowers in the summer months.
SciName: Juncus acutiflorus ehrh. ex hoffm. : Juncaceae : Poales : :

LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Highland (Scotland), Clashnessie, Loch An Easain (nr.)

NarNarrative: This species is common in the northern temperate zone in Europe, Asia and North America. It is found throughout the British Isles. It grows in wet environments with peaty soils, such as bogs and moorland areas. It is easily identified by its fruit, which are arranged in star-like brown clusters, giving the plant its common name.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Muckle Moss
UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Clara Vale

NarNarrative: This species is found in the temperate and arctic regions of North America, Europe and Asia. It is restricted to wet, mossy peatland in mountainous areas. It grows up to 30 cm high, and spreads via an extensive network of long, creeping shoots.

This sedge species is native to marshes, fens and seasonally inundated grassland. Although it is relatively uncommon in Britain it can be very abundant in the locations where it grows. It can be found in temperate areas throughout Europe and Asia, on a variety of different soils.

This grass-like plant is native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia and has been introduced to North America. It has long, upright leaves and stems and grows in small clusters in wet places. It is semi-aquatic, and will grow in several centimetres of water. It is very similar to several other species, and can only be identified by the structure of its tiny flowers, which have just three petals.
